author: Richard Hartley-Parkinson
title: Horrible messages from troll who called Katie Price’s disabled son a ‘c**t’ and a ‘m**g’
text:
Mark Williams has deleted 3,000 tweets A troll who targeted a host of celebrities and asked ‘can we hang all the gays’ appears to have turned shy after being exposed.
 
Mark Williams, 30, from Stockton-on-Tees, has deleted 3,000 tweets and apologised to Katie Price for calling her son Harvey a ‘m***’ and a ‘c***’ saying he ‘never thought she would read it’.
Williams said he hoped the the 14-year-old, who has Prader-Willi syndrome, would ‘choke on some sweets’ and edited a picture of a bag of Haribo Tangfastics to say ‘Harveybo Tan ’.
A video posted by Katie Price (@officialkatieprice) on Jan 24, 2017 at 2:17pm PST 
A video posted by Katie Price (@officialkatieprice) on Jan 24, 2017 at 2:19pm PST 
Katie Price pictured with son Harvey – Katie has long battled against internet trolls (Picture: Rex Shutterstock) His sudden change of heart came after The Sun newspaper approached him about his tweets. They said that when they approached him ‘shrugged his shoulders’ adding ‘I’m not interested.’
He did, however, add that he was ‘sorry if he upset Harvey’.
Williams Twitter history also revealed that he had sent abuse to Cheryl Cole and Taylor Swift, showed support for Adam Johnson and asked ‘Can we hang the gays?’
Harvey’s brother, Junior, 11, defended him on instagram against trolls.
A video posted by Katie Price (@officialkatieprice) on Jan 24, 2017 at 2:19pm PST 
How to spot a troll Some of the marks of the troll are obvious – such as a habit of having posts deleted. Others are less so, such as a reluctance to use full stops and commas.
Cornell and Stanford University researchers found that they could spot trolls with around 80 per cent accuracy simply from looking at the language they used.
The team studied comments on three sites – CNN, right-wing news site Breitbart and gaming site IGN – and looked for patterns.
Trolls aren’t keen on full stops or capitals 

Generally speaking, trolls tend to shun punctuation, swear more and make comments which are less readable, the researchers found.
Trolls tend to bang on and on about the same topic 

The researchers found that users who went on to be banned tended to restrict themselves to a few comment threads, and on provoking people into responding to them there.
Trolls tend to sound a bit different from everyone else 

Trolls use slightly different language from other users – they tend not to fit exactly into the technical jargon of sites such as IGN, and use more negative words.
Trolls will not let it drop 
(Picture: Getty) One of the most reliable ways to spot trolls is that they keep posting replies once they’ve got someone interested.
Users who went on to be banned tended to post repeatedly in the same comments threat, replying again and again.
Trolls don’t care if posts are deleted 

If you’re wondering whether someone is a troll, have a look at their comment history.
Many sites are slow to block trolls – and trolls tend to have dozens of comments deleted before they are finally blocked.
If you are dealing with someone a bit troll-ish, it’s a good way to spot them.
